r7XAP0mB1kKnsnJMLBZh2Q.text: Jen Café is a family business. When i went there i only saw women working! If you pass in front of the cafe you will surely see through the window a woman making the dumplings. So yes it's hand made, so yes when it's in your plate fried or steamed it's yummy good. But the place is small, busy and noisy, so you better eat up your yummy hand made dumplings quickly because you don't want to stay there for long.What's not to be missed : the dumplings of course ! if you like them steamed then the bejing dumplings are made for you! the tea is not bad, but i would say that they are tea specialist as they claim.Money, money, money : it's overall very cheap. It's one of the main reason people go there when they pass in front the shop. They see the woman making the dumplings, they look at the prices, and then they enter. That usually how it works. Count around £5 for 8 dumplings, £3.50 for a bubble tea, £5-6 for a large bowl of noodles.That little thing : i would say the home made dumplings. And maybe also the special lunch menu where you get noodles AND rice and a drink for £6.50. Just watch the wall, it changes daily.What needs to be work on : The list is pretty long, first maybe the place, it's quite small and it gets crowded very quickly. Plus the seating are not cosy at all. The place is not clean, the tables sticky from the previous meal, and the floor very dirty.Verdict : it's ideal if you want a quick cheap lunch and eat good dumplings, but if you seek for something else, just keep looking.

DSG2FAV_NHn_0jPanEe-lg.text: Great little place. Really tasty dumplings and great bubble tea. I really want to go back! Not expensive at all!

4_gD7O1X8D9glSRJ8H7usQ.text: So happy when I found this place while searching online for a chinese restaurant that serves homemade dumplings!It's pretty much a hole in the wall in the middle of China town, however the food speaks louder than how this place looks. There's a little chinese lady  by the window relentlessly folding dumplings while tourists pass by to check out what she's doing. Dumplings both steamed and fried are delicious!! It tastes just like the dumplings I have back in Cali. The chinese style jja jja mein (black bean sauce with homemade noodles) are a little less than average. The fried bbq pork is amazing! Very juicy but crispy on the outside. Anyways, its cash only so remember to stop by the cash machine before you make your way in. =)

byMlXNt7E64fAeA0VpHFnQ.text: solid dumplings, except I have never been treated so poorly at a restaurant in my life! the owner was extremely rude and pushy. we went to grab a late lunch (business was rather slow), and she basically was trying to get us to wolf down our food and get out of the restaurant. when I asked for an extra plate so we could divide up our order, she yelled at me saying no one was allowed a plate no exceptions.

photos.caption: Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. ladies at work
Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom

I4x07OXdBUN_atV0dHMp3g.text: I love this place!  The dumplings...they are fantastic.  Fried or steamed they are delicious!  And I love washing it down with a bubble tea...so far the best I've had in London.  The Pork Noodle soup...it was ok...  the noodles were mushy and didn't hold up very well, but the flavour of the soup was good.  For the price, I think it is a great value and I prefer to take my lunch to go and sit outside.  Not to mention the service is fast!

_tbOV4jjcyqmsbgSA-OWVg.text: Slightly grungy place that serves typical Chinese fare. Baozi Inn was closed for the day, so my friend and I hopped over to Jen Cafe hoping for some good bubble tea. The tea itself was good, but the bubbles were hard and slimy. Mission half accomplished? My combination rice was only so-so and my friend said her vegetable dumplings were also just average. Service was quick and friendly. It gets fairly crowded at lunch time. There are definitely better places in Chinatown, but it's not bad for a quick, authentic Chinese meal. Next time, if there is a next time, I'll order the meat dumplings and tea sans bubbles.

pRROF7Cf_D7pla_FOfO4IQ.text: Having recently recommended Jen Cafe for bubble tea, I felt duty-bound to return to check whether it was as good as I remembered.Jen Cafe is very aptly named and is a reminder of the hawker stall experience in Malaysia - small tables, people sharing, waitresses remembering your order without writing it down, general hubbub but somehow the right dish arrives at the right table.There's a good choice of regular drinks, ice drinks and bubble tea with pearls - tapioca based with sugar giving the chewy bullets at the bottom of the drink. I chose the melon and it was nice to see fresh fruit going into all the bubble drinks. My melon could have been a bit sweeter but that's not the fault of the cafe.I also had crispy pork with lo mein and an order of their signature Beijing dumplings. The dumplings were nice but not outstanding with the wrapper verging on being a little thick. The crispy pork was nice.Worth a look for a quick meal or for some takeaway bubble tea.

fblcTk70SX9Q-8ky0I31-g.text: I have to go here when I'm in town.  I don't want new, might be good, might not be good places, I want to go here and stuff my face with dumplings.  I LOVE dumplings in all shapes and forms (perogies, shumai, ravioli) and when I go here, I have to order ALL of them whether or not they fit in my stomach.  After 3 times, I have learned the veggie dumplings seem like a good idea, but, not really.  They are not as interesting as the meat ones.  I order both ways; steamed and pan-fried.  The bubble tea is decent, especially the mango.  I'm not sure, but I think they don't do credit cards here, so have cash.I always find myself here between meals (less busy) and when it's raining (very cosy).  The service is quick and efficient, not very friendly but as long as they put dumplings in front of me, I don't really mind.

W5mOHo0TJ06RNgtLG4IPGw.text: Dummmmmpppplllingggsss . .  :)Since I've been in London, I've been looking for a dumpling/noodle spot.  And I found this little spot!  Great place to grab a quick meal - food comes out fast.  && nothing beats some good ol' homemade noodles and dumplings. YUM.This place reminds me of my trips to Beijing.  It's a small place, which includes table sharing, but enough arm space to use chopsticks! [for all my chopstick users out there, you know what that means . . :P]I definitely recommend this spot if you're craving some dumplings/noodles or even if you don't even feel like cooking.  Cheap prices £10 or less per person, depending on what you get.

0Lox5GF9qPXdk6c-P9IAmw.text: FOOD:this was our absolute favorite place in chinatown to go.  their dumplings and noodles are homemade and boy you can tell when you eat them!  this woman stands in this corner window all day long and just rolls out dumplings and she has really mastered it.  the other food there is decent, but we just always went for dumplings.  SERVICE:typical chinese restaurant service- you're going there for food, not the service.  seating is very limited so you're probably going to be sitting next to strangers and on a random stool instead of a chair. turnaround time is fast, but the wait for fresh dumplings is so worth it.AMBIANCE:again, the same as your typical chinese restaurant (the kinds in the american chinatowns, not the london chinatown).  it's small and dingy, but usually these are the best places to go.

lNgw27v1XfIHHJbVm72dkQ.text: Jen Café is a Chinatown institution and has been on its corner site on Newport Place for as long as I can remember. It's very much a caff reminiscent of the cha chaan tengs of Hong Kong serving a wide choice of hot drinks and breakfast stuff like toasted sandwiches. Whilst the bulk of the menu consists of Cantonese BBQ served with a choice of rice and noodles, there's only one reason why you come here and that's for their hand-made jiaozi or Beijing dumplings. These dumplings remind me of Beijing and you know they're hand-made as you can see the ladies making them in the shop window. I ordered the jianjiao or fried dumplings (£5/8 pcs) but you can also order boiled dumplings (£4.50/8 pcs). There was a bewildering choice of drinks but being a bit of an old git, I ordered a tankard of hot chrysanthemum tea (£1.20). The dumplings were perfectly pan-fried with a nice char on the outside. As these are Northern Chinese dumplings, they're more rustic than Cantonese dim sum but what they lack in delicacy they make up for in taste. The filling of pork, spring onion, chives, and Chinese leaf was juicy and was complemented well by the traditional vinegar dip. All in all, Jen's handmade dumplings make for a great snack or to share as a side order with a one-plate meal.

bUlZsRp98Ul9HopoTx_oIw.text: A tiny little place on the corner with communal tables which can get very busy at times. I go there as I love their three roast meats combo with rice. The service is a little unfriendly and ultra efficient. As my coke was emptied into my glass without a comment and then the can was thrown away which is a little bit rude to me. However I forgive them for that. Do watch the ladies by the window making dumplings. Its amazing how quickly they can make a dumpling. But alas I've yet to try one as I'm lazy and go for the easy option everytime here.

qptsci2U9QtA7MrGLXhl3g.text: Nothing fancy here, but home made noodles and dumplings. Simple, inexpensive, and right in the middle of all the action. Not a big place and there are plenty of places to grab a bite to eat while you wait (buns, hot pot, etc).

94D8WKsBpGNbNUAv--7Y4Q.text: I've eaten here twice and each time was not very enjoyable, the service is lacking (and a bit rude) and the tables were dirty...which makes me question my utensils. Ew. But they do have the best bubble tea in China Town! They have a lot of veg options, but do not venture to the noodle side of things...it's sketchy, my friends and I have all gotten stomach aches. Samosas are unimpressive and small, but the dumplings were good.I'll have to pass on the atmosphere, but will not be hesitant order my bubble tea to go.

I5seR7ZO2JjkG6RCJj-meA.text: This cafe is totally unassuming, a green shop front on a corner in Chinatown, but it is usually pretty full at most hours of the day, mainly I imagine because it is exactly everything you could possibly want from a cheap as chips Chinese in central London. There is always a woman making pork and cabbage dumplings in the window and these are the best things to get here, steamed or fried and served in generous portions. The noodle dishes are also pretty nice and again, ridiculously cheap. You sit where there's space at tables that often become communal as there's not much seating and you find yourself sharing with a mix of the local Chinese community and young trendies. An excellent no frills place to swing by if you become overwhelmed by the choice of restaurants all doing pretty much the same thing in Chinatown. The pervasive smell of bleach can be a little off-putting.

w3RupCD_AKUJmIbRl1v8tA.text: The first dish of dumplings that we ordered were tasty, so we thought we were on to a good find in the hotch-potch of offerings in Chinatown. However, the won-ton's were a really doughy and then it went downhill from there. As none of the waitresses seemed to speak English it was a real stuggle to tell them our noodles did not match our order and when we asked for additonal spoons and chopsticks to share our communal selection of dishes we were told 'you have enough chopstick'. We were shoved the bill before we could order more driinks to wash down the MSG, or finish the two full dishes of food still remaining on our table. For service like this, I'd rather go to China. There are plenty of other places where I can get decent food and service in London.

y47wz1-d8lgtUOClnvJ7eg.text: Great place for a quick bite, or a drunken feed. It's all about value here. Feed four people with drinks for little more than £20. the menu is limited so it is best to just stick to the dumplings, which are all delicious. Don't expect a "dining experience", just great dumplings at a great price.

SZ4NodI6ylMapL9m5JEJpQ.text: hungryinlondon.com/2011/…  Even though I must have walked past Jen Cafe a million times and was always more than intrigued by the Chinese lady sitting in the window of this small Chinese eatery making dumplings, it needed the heartfelt recommendation of Eat Noodles Love Noodles (read his review of Jen Cafe here) to finally convince me to give it a try. Entering Jen Cafe on the corner of Chinatown, I felt like I had left London and ended up somewhere in China. Half of the waitresses don't even speak English. You wouldn't exactly call Jen Cafe stylish with its metal floor and furniture that has seen its best times (which were not very good even then) probably 30 years ago. I had not even finished placing my order when the food was already in front of me. This was just as well as Jen Cafe doesn't invite to linger. I just had to try the home-made Beijing Dumplings (5) and I did not regret this choice. The generous portion of steamed dumplings with meat-based filling was very tasty indeed. In fact they tasted far better than they looked Even though the dumplings would have been probably plenty for my lunch, my culinary curiosity made me order also the Pork and Pickled Cabbage with Noodles (5) from the board of specials. This soup was rather insipid and I got the confirmation that not even Chinese spices can turn cabbage into something interesting. Jen Cafe gets additional points for entertainment. Half way through my meal one of the waitresses wordlessly put loads of food I had not ordered on my table. Intrigued I watched as she brought shredded chicken, vegetables and burritos and finally takes the seat opposite me (I should mention that my table was small and the restaurant was not full). Still without a word she started rolling herself a burrito and heartily eating it completely ignoring my presence. I decided to quickly leave, somehow I didn't feel very welcome Jen Cafe is not the best place I have ever eaten at but it's fun, cheap and definitely worth a visit to enjoy home-made dumplings. I would recommend though not to choose the table the closest to the counter, she is not going to share her burritos with you!

NrPkTjc0bSeqbvyCEwMzyQ.text: Beijing dumplings are loaded with green onion, ginger, pork goodness; satisfying my dumpling fix until I get back to my beloved Dumpling House in Toronto.

photos.caption: Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. First bite of Beijing dumpling.
Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. An order of Beijing dumplings for 5$

_x6mtwIwZa3v2dGEFg9STw.text: Jen Cafe is one of a few reasons I would ever go into Chinatown for chinese food. Firstly it is definitely a cafe, not fancy at all and service is very rushed and definitely do not expect manners as for most chinatown restaurants. It is like a chinese greasy spoons without the warm smile not even for a regular.But it is one of the places in London where I can forgive the restaurant for bad service as it is part of the experience if you're planning to eat in Chinatown in the first place.The cafe itself is very small, cheap metal tables and seats, plastic cutlery and plates, bright green walls and an 'out of service' sign always stuck on their toilet which makes it all very unwelcoming. But I like it and especially when they make the most fresh and delicious Beijing dumplings in London. And you should only come here for their dumplings and their popular variations of Bubble tea. Only use the other items on the menu as a stomach filler for the more hungry ones as the quality would not match the dumplings at all.You can tell it's fresh from the lady sitting facing the window making the dumplings in front of you as you walk by and there is a choice of either pork or vegetarian and then boiled or pan fried. I always go for the pork just because it is more fragrant and then a portion of it being pan-fried for £6.00 and a portion of boiled for £5.00. They are like no other Beijing dumplings anywhere else in London. First of all they are made from glutinous rice flour rather than all-purpose or plain flour. This provides a more lighter and softer pastry, more sticky which makes the dumplings more moist, making it a delight to eat. The filling is perfectly seasoned and flavoured well with chives and other ingredients. Flavours are definitely not lacking here.Whether it is pan fried or boiled both varieties comes to you piping hot. Even though I always order both varieties I always preferred the boiled ones as it's a fresher, cleaner taste, more squidgy and holds more of the pork stock inside. However I know many prefer the pan-fried just for that smokey flavour and crispy base. Once it's left on your table it's to your customisation with the condiments on your table and the platelets given. The usual mix tends to be a spoonful of vinegar and half of that in soy sauce and then chilli oil to your preferred spice level. Of course you can keep adding each to get the flavour you want.As a stomach filler I would recommend the noodle soup dishes to the rice dishes as I find their meat over rice a bit too greasy with fatty and poor in quality meat. I always go for their special which is shredded pork and pickled cabbage with rice noodles and make sure you ask for rice noodles or they will give you instant noodles instead. So the noodles aren't the best quality, a bit plasticky but for the price of £5.50 I'm not complaining because it is the pork and pickled cabbage that flavours the broth making it very appetising and warming to the soul with the meaty, savoury and sour taste. You can always spice it up with the chilli oil on your table too.Depending on what time you go it is always quite packed and yes service is very rushed and they will throw the bill at you straight after you finish your last bite so a bit of warning there. But with that in mind and a bit of openness you will find yourself having a very nice delicious, quick yet filling meal there. Definitely not a place for a romantic meal but for good quality, authentic Beijing dumplings.

photos.caption: Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Special menu
Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Shredded pork and pickled cabbage rice noodle soup
Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Beijing dumplings

2YRptOCziEZNKVXvvO7gkQ.text: I love this place. I know the service is not great- the staff are often pushy and a bit annoying, even at their best- and I know the seating is a bit odd (getting sat next to strangers at the same table can be a bit weird!), but the dumplings? Well, they make up for everything. It's wonderful watching people make dumplings from scratch in the window, and when you taste them, they're even better. I actually think everything pork-based from this place is amazing-- at least, I have yet to try something I disliked. Wonderful assortment of teas, as well. The price is, of course, the real winner- you always leave feeling full and satisfied!

SnFD-wrq7Ik4yVs9R6kiMw.text: Chinese canteen style. Squished against strangers. A simple look, even if slightly abrasive.  But I love that part of the experience.Jen's Cafe, I believe, serves Beijing style food. You can usually see one of the few ladies who work there, rolling out and making fresh dumplings in the window. Arguably, this is what they are best known for. The vinegar and chilli oil are out and ready for your bundles of joy to be dunked in and savoured.I often like a lighter dumpling and will order a bowl of steamed vegetarian Beijing dumplings. While enjoying them, I watched the fried dumplings go past. They're not the deep-fried within an inch of their lives like some places do it. Put lightly pan fried on one side, sharing the duality of chewy and crunching in one bite.Oh, I had made a big mistake.Recently, not intending to let them pass me by again, I ordered (and shared!) both steamed and fried dumplings. Good choice Jhenn. Good choice. I was also pleased to learn their vegetable soup option is vegetarian (no homemade noodles though). Although lacking in flavour, it was nothing the stacked-high condiments couldn't fix (helllooooooo chunky chilli oil!)Overall, I really like Jen's Cafe and love to take people there to share a plate of dumplings.

BzWGbT013IyjkuLp6KmmZw.text: Cheap and tasty, don't expect good service here.  Get in, stuff your face and get out!  But oh so good.Have tried several things on their menu and the one thing I would always recommend is the fried dumplings.  Pan fried crispy perfection on the outside with a thin dough and meaty filling in the middle.  Selection of standard sauces on the table.  Hands down best dumplings in London.The roasted meats are not as good as other places in Chinatown so I would skip those.  Get the fu xian ball soup though, it's a great accompaniment to the dumplings.

photos.caption: Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Best dumplings in London
Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Fu xian ball soup
Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Pork and cabbage noodle soup

9pe4ZgstjsIquvxoj4VVzQ.text: Damn, dumplings are expensive here.For 5 pounds, they just gave me 6 or 7 dumplings. Not to mention, the 'skin' of the dumpling is quite thick and rough... They serve instant noodles in their noodle dishes, which I don't quite fancy. Meh, just overpriced. I've had better.

cQZB2mgYMZn2LbWf7FAUoQ.text: Tiny place at the edge is Chinatown.  Service was courteous indeed.  Dumpling is their bread and butter, so that's also decent.  The soup noodle was overwhelming flavorful, perhaps because of the msg.  Overall 3 stars.

z9wvRTUKr2S8pBM9QHk7Wg.text: Review for their boba (bubble) milk tea only - quite average and overpriced (at just over 3 pounds). Almost no boba balls were in my cup, nothing special here at Jen.

photos.caption: Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom

-ZqvrNzK2WUDbk-1O178lw.text: Admittedly, I only stopped into Jen Café to get a bubble tea to take away.  But the façade DOES say 'Jen Café   Tea Specialist'.  I'd found the place on Yelp, having read someone else's proclamation that it offered 'the best' bubble tea in London.It was rainy and dreary as I trekked the mile from my place of work during my lunchbreak for a bubble-tea indulgence; I was looking forward to this wonderful drink making my day brighter.The café wasn't busy. I placed my order, and the woman behind the counter invited me to take a seat while they prepared my mango bubble tea.  I peered around and found the café's decor to be spartan and a bit tatty.  But, hey, it's cheap-and-cheerful Chinatown, right?Ultimately what the score comes down to is this: the bubble tea itself.  It was blended with ice, which I wasn't expecting but wouldn't be, all things considered, a deal breaker.  Nevertheless, the ice hadn't been completely broken down in the blending process, which resulted in a, well, rather icey consistency - not at all appealing, especially not with the cool, dismal weather going on outside at the time.Would I go back to try another bubble tea in future?  Possibly. I DO have a love that some people might call unnatural for drinks with jiggly balls in them.Was the one I got on that day 'A-okay'?  No.  Its only redeeming factor was the aforementioned jiggly balls, which would, indeed, make anything better; let's be honest here.

photos.caption: Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom

V26FcctQHdVYJl7RQ07S2g.text: Yum!! If you are after great dumplings and delicious bubble tea this is the spot!

photos.caption: Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Hard to beat!!

0ViNDhwsjuwghT60Bd9tkQ.text: Just up from Leicester Square station is a dandy stop for the best Beijing Dumplings around! Situated in a bright green wedge of a building you can see everything going on inside through the large windows. You may see a woman rolling dough and fashioning dumplings through the corner window right on the point. They have other items as well but the dumplings, boiled, fried or souped are delicious and filling any way you like them! And the prices  (£5) are right if you just want to fill up and not be ripped off by all the high priced restaurants in the area. The interior is small, tables are sometimes shared and they decor isn't anything special but you get what you pay for. And yeah, I had to ask for a glass of water four times before the waitress who looked like she would rather be doing something else brought it.But I'd still go back for the dumplings!!!

dGcUDV5W1i8Ed8jblqhU6A.text: The Beijing dumplings were not special at all like other yelpers were saying.  We are from California USA and dumplings we tried were tasty and fresh with pillow soft skins.  These were thick skinned and ordinary flavor.  Also, it is un-appetizing to eat on old , worn down plates and bowls.

MiVmjhn4PJ3W4Aj0vlNMjA.text: I have never written a review before but hopefully this will save another potential customer from wasting there time and money at this place. Went in for a quick snack. Ordered two dishes. When the food came out we asked for plates and this is the first (hopefully last) restaurant I've ever been where they said no! Pretty incredible and makes me wonder how they were ever in business to begin with. I hope no one else ever eats here.

SBL6o65pWqrOEpGgf0dReg.text: I dream of the Beijing dumplings. I do a happy dumpling dance everytime I go. The dumplings are fresh, fresh, fresh!

RBvJ7nIhAUEnsF1dDo0_fg.text: Only had the boiled Beijing dumpling with chive and pork. Soooo good, great condiments to go with and made fresh to order.

zmwwUNDef-uWE870zoiZlw.text: Ordered octopus and lo mein. I asked the server for recommendations and found her to be causally indifferent. My octopus was rubbish (or just rubber) and the noodles were of the Cup o' Noodles variety - truly. Conclusion? My fault. Should've ordered what everyone was saying on Yelp: dumplings. They looked great on everyone else's plate.

dKOpua18Yr3zY3af0AuFSg.text: Most people save their landmark reviews for something special.This is my 200th review, and no, I did not save it just for Jen Cafe. Jen Cafe, just happens to be the lucky recipient.I suppose it is not entirely unceremonious, however, in that I am 1/4 Chinese, and DO have an irrational love for dumplings. My mum and I stopped in here famished (but having an early dinner reservation, not wanting to eat too much), We just sat at the counter, and had one order of vegetable dumplings, and one order of pork dumplings. Really hit the spot.This place is not easy if you are unfamiliar with Chinese food. It is quite "Chinese" and very little direction is given by the menu or the staff. When I go back, I'll have more dumplings and try the bubble tea as well. Didn't even know they had it. Both were delicious. I miss my mummy. sniff.

GBGPAC9Qu-64eBMeV0egpA.text: I only come here for their dumplings, they're one of the best I've had in Chinatown. You'll usually see a lady making dumplings by the window. Food here is very cheap however the service is absolutely awful. If you're not too bothered about it then definitely try it out

GO0SzbQUvq6PISTATzo1gQ.text: Service here is not a priority, but if you're craving fresh dumplings then this trip to Chinatown is worth it! This tiny little restaurant is on the corner of Newport Place so it's really easy to find and really convenient. I would not suggest bringing a large party into this place - I think the largest table could hold maybe 6 people.I ordered:-Deep Fried Squid Rings (super tasty and not too chewy)-Beijing Dumplings (the wrapping was super good and the filling was equally tasty, to be honest, the menu didn't indicate what was in these dumplings but I sure as hell didn't care after I ate them, haha)-Roast Duck with Rice (the duck was way too salty for my taste, but the flavor was just right)I ordered these as a take-away and I was out of there in about 10 minutes. I can definitely see myself craving their dumplings again.

r1dIKeWU68dim5AoQGoi2w.text: It's kind of a dump and, like other Yelpers have said, it's driven mostly for the Chinese crowd.  The English on the menu isn't very helpful so it's best to bring a translator friend.Jen and fam serves no frills street food as one would find in Asia - dumplings, noodles and rice.  It's no place to wine and dine your date.  Just sit, eat and bounce - very transactional.It's a small operation, so best arrive in groups of no more than four.  Ideally limit to two with the expectation of sharing a table with strangers.

k95L2JGQUuXL1CqzkTcO7w.text: When the sign reads fresh dumplings and there's a guy in the window rolling dumplings. Uhhh you have to stop in! The dumplings are truly fresh!! We had them steamed, fried, pork and vegetarian. All terrific!

photos.caption: Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom

1VGcZT3qZLFJlzxx5dPJ7A.text: There are so many better food selections in Chinatown than this cafe... but I ended up here because not many other stores were open. Their wontons are super super SUPER small and their handmade dumplings were lacking... I was super sad... it was not really notable even though it's supposed to be what they're known for. The best thing on the table, surprisingly, was a cha siu (bbq pork) and braised duck platter with rice. It was delicious with the sweet bbq pork sauce mixed into the rice... a reminder of my childhood palate.I saw the lady making jiajiangmian knife-cut noodles by hand in the window that made me want to try it but didn't (maybe that's the dish to go for there as well).

photos.caption: Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. * Handmade pork and leek dumplings... ok but not memorable.
Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. * Delicious chasiu (bbq pork) and duck with white rice.

IAiIqS3S2p3chWZISwLBAg.text: We wanted a place to just sit and rest our feet, and this place had a menu outside that had bubble tea. I went in and it felt a lot like the cha can tengs in HK - so I was super excited to order the yuen yang (coffee / tea). I also tried to order a sandwich with scrambled egg / luncheon meat, but was told that they no longer have sandwiches there. The yuen yang was decent - not great, but I haven't had it since I left HK two years ago so my nostalgia might've been triggered. My travel companion got the cold lemon tea, which was also decent. Our server made us feel like she just wanted us out since we were ordering drinks, which is understandable - but there were a couple tables open so we didn't feel too bad.The girl next to us had fried dumplings, which looked pretty good - didn't try them myself but it looked / smelled yummy!

Otvm0g2E68X1eqTpZqJkuQ.text: We only got the fried dumplings, and they were tasty. A little too oily for my liking, but still great. The filling was fresh and dumpling itself was crispy. The restaurants atmosphere would be about a 3/10.

photos.caption: Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom

EXciemXeBonisuRUCidawA.text: My name is Jenn so how can I NOT give this place a chance when I'm visiting Chinatown in London?Fiancé and I ordered the fried Beijing dumplings and it was indeed decent. We're Chinese so we know what's up with those dumplings and nope, they did not disappoint. Give it a try and you'll be coming back for more.

1h4xxNJDya-ltyAwU646Ew.text: We dined at Baozi Inn a couple nights before and saw Jen Cafe with two workers hand making the dumplings behind the window. We then wanted to try this out. Ordered 1 vegetable steamed dumpling (7 pieces), 1 pork and preserved vegetable soup noodles, 1 BBQ pork ramen, and a vegetable order of bok Choi. Overall we thought this was a good hearty meal that's comfort food for the two of us on our holiday that love Asian food. This is definitely a place for local Asians to dine at as well as some other London locals looking for cheap Chinese food. Would recommend this place for a cheap eat and good alternative if you can't get into Baozi Inn. Note that the restaurant only has 5 or 6 tables so seating is limited!

photos.caption: Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. BBQ pork ramen
Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Vegetable dumplings
Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Preserved vegetable ramen

HkGnpvYsr5aYkWjSrwgVpQ.text: A very tiny cafe restaurant, but the food is very, very authentic. You feel like you are dining in a similar place in the Far East.  The seating is quite tight and cosy since the place is small, so you are expected to share tables, which I do not find a problem with, as you are there to eat the food and leave, definitely not to linger.  As soon as seats are vacated it is quickly filled again, so a very buzzy feel to the place.  We shared a plate of 7 fried dumplings, and I ordered the fried fish balls and noodle soup and my friends had the beef noodle soup and BBQ pork with rice.  The duck and chicken was already finished even though it was only 6.30pm, but understandably, since they are famed for their dumplings, they are not really bothered to keep that in high stock. Oh my, I have not tasted fried fish balls with noodles so tasty for a long time!  It definitely evokes memories eating street food in the far east, the hor-fun noodles were so fresh and rather like pho in texture and taste.  An absolutely delicious bowl of yumminess!

UMLGzmop8U6LlsucfaKXfQ.text: If you're looking for delicious dumplings with no excess this place is it. It's small, and charming like what you'd expect in China town. I ordered steamed dumplings and duck and rice. Both were amazing and just what I wanted in when I think of both - dumplings were fresh, the filling was flavorful and the duck was seasoned well and delicious and comforting. No frills. Someone next to me ordered fried dumplings and those too looked great. (BTW they seat others w you if there's space. This place wouldn't be great for a larger group; 10-15 tables max)You can catch the dumplings being made b/c everything happens right there!Go for the fast and delicious food.

OmDd89mdlk8lGgsyCLXY8A.text: Buyer beware. Not all restaurants with hand made noodles and dumplings deserve a visit. This restaurant lured us in with their excellent location and window display of workers rolling out dumplings. There was no taste to the food. The staff was super friendly but was nothing that we expected in the food. Noodles and dumpling skins were too thick unlike most of the better dumpling houses. The sauces missed the flavor target. Would not return.

0iegV7Zs1E8SBZq3CteZaw.text: My favourite Chinese dumpling restaurant in London. Really good and fresh dumplings heat are made in front of you. This is not cheap Chinese takeout. Be aware that you probably need 3 orders of dumplings to be full, so 18-20 gbp. It's the price you pay for quality food.

0FIen0j_yOaJKACBJ0PvUQ.text: Fresh dumplings all the time, and they are fantastic.It's a fast moving cafe and if you're going to take your time, I wouldn't really recommend coming here, it's designed to be a place where you go in, order, eat and leave. Being such a small place, it's cash only, and be prepared for it. In terms of what you order, it's dumplings all the way, order them fried, steamed or in soup, you can't go wrong in my opinion. As for the other items, I've never had any.Seating arrangement will seem a little strange to people, they will sit you at a table with other people if you're a smallish group (tables fit 4 so if you're a 3, you might get a random). It's not that new a thing, and very common in Asia quick eat places. In fact it's kinda like Wagamama without having the long tables. But you aren't here for a long meal, you're there to sit, eat some dumplings and head on to the rest of your day/evening. For me, it's a quick bite to eat before continuing with my real plans.

VVBe60ZvxR-V2ovA0vimuw.text: Looking at the other reviews of this place I notice that while most tell of the basic, cramped surroundings and somewhat terse service, no-one else seems to have thus far mentioned the 20 minute time limit if you only have drinks... Even while sharing a table with strangers who are tucking into plates of dumplings.Having already eaten a big meal less than half an hour ago, I just want to relax with some Chrysanthemum tea, which quickly arrived (sweetened) in a mug but is too hot to drink right away.Fiteen minutes later and it is just about cooled enough for me to start drinking - I'm not one of the many gifted with an asbestos mouth, unfortunately.As I'm nearing eviction, I might order something sweet as the "dessert" to my earlier meal; or I might see if they suddenly pour the remainder of my tea into a doggie bag and usher me out of the door... The waiter has been coming over and checking my progress every two or three minutes, having already presented me with the bill at the same time as my drink!No. I really couldn't eat anything more right now (the sugary tea took me to my limit) so I will make a dignified exit while I can - despite the fact that there are now several vacant spaces, should a sudden onrush of new customers occur.I must remember to starve myself before I go back there again, as I do want to try those freshly made dumplings everyone raves about. The lady in the window has been making them non-stop the whole time, and I can see her still at it from my vantage point where I'm perched on the little pagoda opposite as I finish writing this.To summarise, a reasonably priced mug - not a pot - of Chrysanthemum "tea" made from instant, sweetened granules (as opposed to the actual flowers) whilst made to feel slightly less relaxed than on a visit to the dentist!

photos.caption: Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. Dumplings in the making.

Px8yzdIO8-sdXf4KYhVLYQ.text: Venturing into (any)Chinatown is always a bit of gambling; you're never quite sure what you'll find. On the other hand; when in the hands of a local, knowledgeable guide it can really open your eyes for the hidden gems.Thus before we arrived at Jen Cafe we had a brief stop at one of the Chinese supermarkets and got pointed out quite a few hidden spots for future reference.The dumplings we had at Jen's weren't bad or anything but the dough was imho to thick and made what I consider a meal in the lighter end of the spectrum a quite heavy experience. The filling and taste was great, but the consistence didn't do the trick for me - unfortunately. ===Disclaimer; this was a stop on a SoHo food safari-thing, so the review may seem rather slim but we only had a few items.

CT4NqYWfwUhmLexPEJIuyg.text: That's the worst chinese restaurant in China Town I think. It can not accept card and I had to find the ATM. The service is not good and staffs are noisy. I will never come back.

aV6QpyMWZMdUD94DCPTh1w.text: A bit overpriced, not too many vegetarian options, indifferent service ... and really tasty dumplings!Couldn't find much on the menu that was vegetarian except the dumplings.  They were flavorful and of perfect texture, especially the fried ones, but would definitely count as appetizer rather than a full meal.  Vegetarians will probably want to go elsewhere.  The shared sauces in the middle of the table were empty and often felt like the servers forgot about us (took a very long time to get my change back when paying the bill).  Also, cash only!

photos.caption: Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. the fried veggie dumplings were delicious
Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. making dumplings in the front window

KAj8fXR2crX--0YRIkKtOg.text: I'm very picky about eating in Chinatown but Jen Cafe has won me over. We stopped for dinner here on a Tuesday night. Normally I see this place packed whenever I walk by but this time it was practically empty. Nevertheless we were still rushed a bit with the bill as soon as we had finished our meal. After reading Wendy L's review apparently this is normal. But don't let that stop you from coming here as the meal is worth it. I ordered the Honey BBQ pork with rice and a mint milk tea. For the price I was happy with the portion, a lot of meat and a good amount of rice to go with it! The pork was delicious but the rice was dry and crunchy in some areas. My boyfriend had better luck with his rice dish; three delicious meats and well cooked rice. Perhaps mine was just a fluke.Our drinks were very tasty. The tapioca pearls are fantastic! Extremely soft and perfectly sweet, out of all the pearls I've tried in London these are the closet in texture and taste to the ones I had in Taiwan. But we only got a few of them in our milk tea, I would have liked a lot more since they were so delicious! The fact that they have mint as a flavour of milk tea is awesome because I love mint and I love trying "unique" flavour options. Cheap, satisfying, good bubble tea. I can't wait to come back.

photos.caption: Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. honey bbq pork with rice
Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. mint milk tea
Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom. three meats with rice

tLS71whohtflXCq-dT2fiw.text: Firstly I read reviews about this place and I knew what the best thing to come for here was - the dumplings. A clue is when you see a woman in the window making them. Don't expect much in service, this is in the heart of Chinatown, but the dumplings are good. We got a batch steamed and fried and the fried ones were much tastier. Crispy exterior enhanced the flavour. Also had a chocolate bubbletea.

photos.caption: Photo of Jen Cafe - London, United Kingdom

lm7w2csIMH1MRFZxvQdGRg.text: The prices here aren't cheap for portions, but they're decent, I guess. My first Chinese meal that I had in London- still the best one.I ordered the BBQ pork rice noodle soup and it was so delicious on a cold, rainy day. Add some hot sauce that's on the table and you'll be good to go. The fried dumplings also looked delicious. Noodle soup is around 5.50 - 6.50 and the dumplings are 6 pounds.  Service isn't too great, you'll have to flag down a waitress and they seem to rush you when it looks like you've finished eating. Also if you have an empty seat in your table, they'll put a stranger in.

vsOu2YImoOvec78Uq5o6qw.text: Really delicious dumplings!  Having spent a lot of time in San Francisco and New York Chinatowns, I would say that the Beijing dumplings are on par with some of my favorites from back home.  The restaurant is a little touristy, but definitely less so than the rest of London Chinatown, and definitely better priced.  Also, you can't expect 5-star service because that's not the type of restaurant this is - it's just a cafe!For £5, I got a steaming bowl of 7 dumplings: the rich porky filling was light and well-balanced by pungent ginger and scallions,  with just the right chew to the skin.  Dipped in some vinegar soy sauce, oh man!  All washed down with a cool, refreshing, frothy pearl mint milk tea, and I feel like I'm back home.  Can't wait to come back!  Cash only.

lvC77jr4FTqMtQK3x0WH0A.text: I have been wanting to try this place for a while, so me and my friend finally popped inside for an impromptu lunch meet. The place is quite small and quite busy during lunch hour, but we managed to be seated straight away.I ordered the soup noodles with roast duck - the soup was maybe a bit bland, but it wasn't too bad when eaten with the roast duck which helped balance out the flavours. You can add extra soya sauce if needed. My friend ordered the hot and spicy pork noodles with sauce. The noodles looked homemade and were quite thick like udon noodles. We saw the table next to us having it so we ordered one ourselves, and it was simple but  quite tasty.We also shared a bowl of wanton soup. I think they use the same soup base for the noodles and dumplings as they taste the same.We were too full to try their dumplings which are supposed to be pretty good, and you can also watch them making them by the window.The food here is simple, tasty and cheap, and I would probably pop back in again soon.
